can you make apache2.conf available as w: you need to purge apache2-common (or apache2.2-common) then reinstall, the "apache2" package won't do that
and, httpd.conf is empty.  Ubuntu (and debian systems) don't use it.  Instead they use a mixture of apache2.conf, and the stuff in sites-enabled, and hte stuff in mods-enabled.
whats the command exactly?
right, im finding that out
you on feisty? or dapper/edgy?
sudo apt-get remove --purge apache2.2-common
thn install apache2 (sudo apt-get install apache2)
Oh, synaptic will work too.  In synaptic, find apache2.2-common, then click it and mark it for "complete removal"
then reinstall apache2 (complete-removal is equivalent to --purge)
purging apache2 won't do it, since the "apache2" package doesn't install the config stuff, apache2.2-common does

purge apache2, apache2.2-common, apache2-utils, apache2-mpm-worker.. and I think that'd be it.  There'll be a few other packages (APR runtimes and stuff), but I dont know if other things depend on those or not
but, those four will remove 90% of apache2, and all of the functionality.

the other few files would be libapr1 and libaprutil1,  mark those for removal, and see if you're removing anything else (that looks like it's not apache related), if so... don't remove them (other stuff might use the APR, I dont know)
